commentBody: Easy 5:36 for a Wednesday - once I caught on to the theme I had a hunch that it was all too related to the new game in my app üòÖ
32 days, that marks my longest streak ever

Making sure that all the O's fall out where you need them to, within six symmetrically placed nine-cell squares, and then not to use any O's anywhere else in the puzzle makes for a difficult task for the constructor.

But unfortunately, it doesn't make an especially scintillating experience for the solver.

But a very fast and easy solve, at least for me.
Anybody else find the crossing of SEITAN and COLON mildly amusing, or is just my adolescent humour?

So the theme is that there are six dice in the grid (tinted squares on my stone tablet), showing 1,2,3,4,5,6 pips.

OK, then.
Nothing like a well-made grid to make me glad this night, and the pips were a nice touch. Woo-woo!

"Do you want this used board game?"
"No dice!"

(I'm on a roll with these puns.)

Figured out the Dice/ Pip theme. Took a bit of staring to actually see the Dice. Relatively easy Wednesday solve. That makes my 2,196 day streak. Yes, I agree with Matthew S. This was ‚Äúrolled out‚Äù to coincide with the new game that premiered today
I was able to solve this ‚Äî with difficulty.ut the theme did not work for me because the 3x3 letter square representing an N on a die contains 9-N irrelevant letters.

I found this a fun puzzle.  Even though it took me five minutes than the Tuesday puzzle, somehow it felt easier.  It must have been difficult for its creator to get the dice to all be upright.  

(I did manage the easy version of the new 'Pips' game, but had no clue as to what was wanted for the medium level.  Even if all I can ever do is 'easy' level, it's still another new game to enjoy.)

The idea behind this one was clever enough, but unfortunately the construction of the grid led to too much 3 letter fill, much of which (e.g. SRO, ANI, ONO) was too familiar crossword fare. The non-pip letters in the dice had no significance to the theme and made the visual less appealing.

Having said that, I did enjoy the two triple O sequences in BOOOFFSTAGE and TOOOFTEN.  MISOSOUP was a welcome addition as well.
Moving along...

What a GEM!  

Loved all the references, especially the I ROBOT. 

But, to be honest, I thought we were initially looking at boggle boards.   Loved how the designer made the pips!
I don‚Äôt get the point of the die/pip theme. Sure, I solved the puzzle, but where was the fun? It was a miss for me.
Anyone else have to run the alphabet for 50A/54D?
Just noticed my Tuesday and Wednesday times were within seven seconds of each other.  Today's was the same amount of easy as Tuesday's was hard.

So that's what they're called, pips. 

And I thought it was a tic-tac-toe puzzle! (face palms)

As a beggar for REGIME change I guess I'm always in "Demo" mode. If only we beggars could be choosers. 

Beggar seems a little harsh. Sounds like Victor or some puzz-editor has had it with panhandlers and mendicants. 

Is there really an art to rolling dice? I ask in all seriousness.
Did not enjoy this theme. Supposed to just tie in with the new NYT game that I'm also not super into? Wow, I try to not be negative on this forum, but I'm going for it today.
Apparently you need to update the app to see the new game!

Wow. The week I decided to jump back into daily crosswords.  

Tues was tough. 
And Wed (tonight), I had to solve to figure out the theme.  But it was very impressive.  No other ‚Äòpips‚Äò in the rest of the puzzle.  And now I‚Äôm thinking about craps. 

I got especially hung up on wetKISS. Then bigKISS. Then finally through the crosses, I got it. 
I considered check puzzle.  Which for a ‚ÄúFriday+‚Äù level solver. Seemed humbling. 

I‚Äôm a big sports fan. But I couldn‚Äôt crack RESEEDED for the life of me. 

I‚Äôm not joking. These early week puzzles have been harder on me than the Friday and Saturday.  

But I love it. I may become a daily solver again (minus Sundays). 

For me, I thought the ‚Äústart of many emotions‚Äù was a clever clue. 

Thank you Victor

For those who don‚Äôt see the point:
First, I thought this was an interesting and pleasant puzzle even if you solved like a themeless (although I did use the Os on the six die). Second, I think there‚Äôs fun in gradually figuring out the theme‚Äîat first I was trying to rearrange letters or see if they SPELT anything. Finally I get enjoyment from appreciating the creativity and artistry and ingenuity of the constructor‚ÄîI know not everyone does, but I do.

The Seneca are one of the Six Nations of the Grand River.
It hasn't been the Five Nations since 1722 when the Tuscarora joined the Haudenosaunee Confederacy.
The Grand River Reserve is about 40 miles west of Toronto.
The Six Nations are Mohawk, Cayuga, Oneida, Onondaga, Cayuga, Seneca and Tuscarora.
It's the largest First Nations reserve in Canada, and a really great place to visit.
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/08/19/wednesday-august-20-2025/#ny

Has anyone else been getting faster every day this week?
Monday: 10:00
Tuesday: 9:46
Wednesday: 8:52

SEITAN??  What planet am I on?  Life is tough enough, trying to decode the Harry Potter chatter in every other puzzle, without the appearance of SEITAN.  

Mr. Schmitt, I was full of admiration for the freshness of so many of your clues, and I thoroughly enjoyed your puzzle, right up to the end, when I realized that ANI was of course not ANa.  SEaTAN was something I just hadn't heard of, but so is SEITAN.  I had to make a trip to the key for that one.

Nevertheless, my warmest thanks for what was otherwise an imaginative, fun solve, and I await your next appearance.

It‚Äôs probably just me, but I got a lot of late 60s, early 70s Brit invasion flashbacks from this one: Exile on Main St‚Äôs Tumbling Dice: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=j9hkUpvUMmE&pp=0gcJCfwAo7VqN5tD BEGGAR‚Äôs Banquet‚Äôs RADICAL Street Fighting Man: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=NHugEELD8o8 The Kinks‚Äô APEMAN and HOLIDAY[S]: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=BBVAS8qNZZI https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=Ao9X3fcLo3k Guess I‚Äôm just [T-REX‚Äôs] 20th Century Boy: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=atmNLbycafM&pp=0gcJCfwAo7VqN5tD

Fim theme, enjoyable puzzle, brutal amounts of concentrated trivia in south east, gotta give something to solve it with.

Shame to be forced into lookups.

I didn't get the dice theme until the very end when I filled in random vowels in the center square and finished with the I in PIP. Huh. I've only seen dice with dots (aka pips), not letters. Would have been nice if there was some kind of animation or colors at the end to make the pips stand out.

Speaking of pips, yes I tried the new game today. Completed all three levels. Didn't find the hard level to be all that hard, just bigger. Maybe I'll try it a few more times, but honestly, I'd rather have Vertex back!!!
A nifty idea, sure, but good lord, all those 3-letter entries‚Ä¶
OOO Yuck.
I enjoyed this puzzle, but I think it‚Äôs to Mr. Schmitt‚Äòs misfortune that‚Äôs the NYT‚Äôs rollout of ‚ÄúPips‚Äù occurred on a Wednesday. It would have made a fine Tuesday offering.

I got the dice theme‚Ä¶ but did anyone else try to figure out what 3-6-2-1-5-4 meant? I‚Äôm not a gambler but thought it might be a lucrative roll‚Ä¶ or a hidden clue‚Ä¶ or a locker combination. (Not really.) So I went to the column for the solution and learned the numbers are‚Ä¶ just dice.

OK. Still a fun puzzle.

DOG KISS. Brings back memories of Charles Schulz, Charlie Brown, Snoopy et al.

Lucy: 'Ugh. I've been kissed by a dog'
I wanted the other letters in the dice to have some sort of significance ‚Äî probably too tall an order to be able to construct that though!
Am I the only one who still doesn‚Äôt get it? I finished it pretty quickly, but what am I missing here???

PIP PIP PIP hooray. 
Clever crossword construction 
Published here today 

That was my weak attempt at a HAIKU ü§® That doesn‚Äôt happen TOO OFTEN. Please don‚Äôt BOO me OFF STAGE. 

Anywho, thank you Victor. This was fun üòä
This puzzle brought to you by the Letter O.
Would've been very cool if the remaining squares on each die were either black or SPELT out something theme-related.

I want to say that I am truly grateful that the NYT Crossword has become a staple in my life. Every day, it takes my mind of the horrors of the modern world we live in. And even though it's just twenty minutes out of my day, it does ground me.

Additionally, I genuinely enjoy the comment section as well and I come here every day. Of course, sometimes there is a little spite, a little condescension, a little frustration. Which we also probably read too much into as well.
But I still do appreciate the intelligent and punny comments that bring a smile to my face.

This community is a good place, you are good people, and I am happy to be a part of it.

I loved this one! I figured out the theme pretty quick (maybe I play too much DnD), and trying to figure out the triple O entries was fun! I‚Äôm admittedly a less talented crossword solver (too young for many references, not american, not a sports guy, etc) but seeing SUE in there was a fun easy entry for me!
Super fun puzzle and theme! And very apt given the recent release of Pips! The SE corner was a bit naticky for me, had a hard time with those entries, but really loved the grid overall!

So, the Brits also call the device Sat Navs. GPS is the signal. In the same way a joke is not funny if it has to be explained to you, so a puzzle isn‚Äôt as good after an explanation. 
I‚Äôll let you off for the spelling of Honor and Odor - lol 

Have a great day puzzlers

One of my favorite puzzles I‚Äôve done recently! Loved the theme and only had to correct one square after I pressed check puzzle at the very end when I got the dreaded ‚Äúalmost there‚Äù pop up. The east side of the puzzle took significantly longer than the west but I stuck with it and was actually able to puzzle it all out :)
A bit upset with this app. I completed this puzzle, but it is not showing as completed in the stats. This happened once before on a 120+ streak. Please advise.

Shortly after one of the worst Sunday puzzles comes probably the worst Wednesday puzzle I've ever done. The theme adds nothing to the solve, there are by my count 36 3 letter answers (surely a record) and there's still room for junky answers like reseeded, sunoco and others.
That was a fun puzzle!  I didn't realize until I read the constructor notes that the only Os were in the pips.  Impressive!

Ugh! üò© Another frustrating solve for me. 36A really threw me because I totally didn‚Äôt see the verse lines in the clue and thought it was the revealer because of the ‚Äúillustrated here,‚Äù so I kept trying to figure out how the shaded squares formed a haiku. Then I got 39A/33D mixed up in my head and kept trying to make 39A ‚ÄúDot.‚Äù In my defense, I woke up at 12:30am and 3:30am, so I‚Äôm going back to bed now. 

I did manage to solve all three levels of Pips yesterday. I think I like it!
Wasn't getting the gimmick until I read the article but I still didn't care....
Clearly, that roll is a ‚Äú6‚Äù!

Tough one for me but managed to work it out. And... must confess I was really not grasping the theme even when I was done. I guess I'm unfamiliar with 'pips' as used in this puzzle. No big deal. Answer history searches today - first did a search for "PIPPI". As I half expected - 'Longstocking' was in the clue for almost every appearance. But.. 'LONGSTOCKING' has never been an answer. And... that did lead me to one of the strangest puzzles I've ever encountered. A Thursday from April 18, 2013 by Stu Ockman. In that one the answers angled up from one part to another with the angled strings being ALP. One example being -- OOL P L A TID (TIDALPOOL) Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/18/2013&g=35&d=A I'm done. ...
I can't be the only one whose weak areas include "hip-hop subgenres" and Harry Potter trivia, so when they converge on one space, 12A/13D, it's especially frustrating. Enough!

As I see the dice rolling through the grid, there are rolls of 3,6,2,1,5, and 4, in that order.  Does the order have any significance (other than the fact that all six possibilities are accounted for)?  What about the other letters on the domino?  Have they no connection to the theme?  Usually Wednesdays don't leave me wanting more.

Any speakers of Etruscan out there? You know, the non-Indo-European language spoken on the Italian peninsula between ~700 and ~50BCE?

Our knowledge of Etruscan is quite limited--easy enough to read, as it was written in a variant of the Greek alphabet, but hard to decipher, as most of the texts are very short, with no long, bilingual ones like the Rosetta Stone, say. Only about a hundred words are understood with reasonable certainty. It doesn't help that most of the texts are funerary inscriptions, so we know the words for "died," "son of," but not much more.

Number words present a particular problem:  a die was found which had words, not pips, on the faces: so scholars knew the words for "one" through "six," but not which was which. It didn't help that not all ancient Italian dice (the ones with pips) had the format 1-6/2-5/3-4 we use today. 

I think most of this has been sorted out, sort of, but it's still unclear if the two words "huŒ∏" and "≈õa" are "four" and "six," or "six" and "four." @Sam l. probably knows, but she's abandonded us, gone, gone, gone:-(
superb puzzle today!

Capital-P Puzzle for me.  Six no-knows.  Many answers that needed crosses before confidently slapping in.  Believing the puzzle had to do with tic-tac-toe after filling in the first two gray areas (Hi, @John Ezra!).  

I like having hills to climb, being riddled with riddles, so this hit my happy place.  

I love the visual mind that envisioned this Pips-Ahoy theme, and the skill behind pulling it off -- making a cogent puzzle out of a dense and extraordinarily constricting theme set, not to mention having no non-pip O's in the grid. 

I enjoyed the Japanese sub-theme, with SEITAN (a word of Japanese origin), MISO SOUP, HAIKU, and NO TIPS (as clued).  Even IMAMORON backward, though it doesn‚Äôt mean anything, has a Japanese feel.

I love the triple-O look of near-neighbors BOOOFFSTAGE and TOOOFTEN (Hi, @Marshall Walthew!), and the PuzzPair¬© of LAB and DOGKISS.

Just a mass of mwah in the box for me.  I‚Äôm a fan.  Thank you so much for this, Victor!

Whew it's been a challenging week so far (but I'm loving it). I thought I might not finish this one, but after staring at the squares and trying to make words out of the nine letters for far too long, I let my mind relax and managed the solve. Very clever and holy cow that must have been hard to construct!! 

My daughter has Celiac so when I see wheat anywhere I feel oddly nervous for her üò¨ ... as a plus, I know the names of many non-wheat grains but wheat grains like SEITAN are not in my vocab. She's doing awesome with it and I'm so grateful for knowledgeable servers and thoughtful restaurant owners for making eating out so much easier for her and others than for those diagnosed even 10 years earlier.

Speaking of which, she's heading to college tomorrow as a first year at UVA (go Hoos!) and while I'm so so excited for her, I'm also feeling many other emotions. Best to all of you who may have kids, nieces, grandkids, etc., especially to first-timers. We got this! (And so do they!) ‚ù§Ô∏èüò≠‚ù§Ô∏è
What does "haiku" have to do with the theme?

Not one of my favorites.  Not a Harry Potter fan and, of late, it seems to be useful for solving the puzzle of late.  Caught quickly that the shaded squares were dice, not that it mattered much.

Please don‚Äôt act like this was a coincidence that this puzzle ran on the day of the introduction of ‚Äúpips‚Äù.  Marketing is marketing.

Glad many liked it.

This one suffered as a puzzle by trying to make a ‚Äúcute‚Äù theme fit. This is kind of why I don‚Äôt care for these kinds of puzzles, I‚Äôm left with a sour experience because the constructor tried to be smarter than they are.

Clever visual theme, which was handled extremely well. Lots of constraints imposed by the many thematic elements, but (to me) the fill didn't seem forced or clunky. 

Never heard of SEITAN, so the E shared by that and SUE was simply a guess, and also the last letter I entered to finish today.

Very nice Wednesday puzzle!

This was such a fun theme! It did help me a tiny bit in a couple of spots and it was nice to admire when I was done.

Another possible clue for 5D: Sat ___ (GPS for kids who watch a lot of Bluey)

Thank you for all the three-letter words. Made it much easier to solve. (Under 9 today with my partner!) Favorite answer = BOO OFFSTAGE ... the constructor's finesse and solver's nagging doubt  on the triple letter
Lots of times, I'll have the theme figured out by the time I reach the revealer(s). Not this time -- and it was a really nice revelation, a great aha moment. I loved this one.

Wow, I‚Äôm surprised that this one wasn‚Äôt more popular, at least according to the comments so far. I really enjoyed it, to the point that I screen-shot it to remember it as a nominee for Wednesday puzzle of the year. 

I didn‚Äôt completely get the theme until the end, but the solve was easy enough, and the revelation was fun for me. I knew of SEITAN but didn‚Äôt know how it was SPELT. Now, thanks to the crossings, I do. 

I give this one a big thumbs up.
But six-sided dice do not have 3 rows or columns on them. What gives?

I knew they were all die faces, obviously, but I kept hoping/assuming there was more to it, that the surrounding letters meant something.  In retrospect I understand what the constructor was limiting themselves to - the only Os were pips - but the shaded squares already took care of that distinction, so his efforts were unnecessary.  (I dutifully read Wordplay this time, hoping for something more.)

In the end it was okay but a little underwhelming, I'm afraid.

Like yesterday, I didn't get the theme until I was almost done.  And, like yesterday, when I finally did the see the theme, it provided a satisfying "Nice!" response from me.  (But I guess I understand those solvers whose response was a disappointed "Meh.")

Not my favorite way to incorporate a theme, but certainly nothing to complain about either.

And the theme did help me get those impressive triple O's in the NW.  (I was afraid that 9-Down was going to be "TOO-O much", and was pleased that I was wrong.)

Eat your Wheaties, folks!
SPELT and SEITAN, that is.

Such is the predominance of politics these days, that I thought for a moment that the Big Apple had a FDT Drive.  :D 
FDR is not top-of-mind.

Pip pip hooray! Thanks for a fun puzzle, Victor.
Speaking of PIPS, love the new game.  However there‚Äôs a problem with today‚Äôs hard puzzle, where I can‚Äôt seem to access the required dominos on my phone.  Anyone have any suggestions?
This was fun! Had ‚Äúlie‚Äù for ‚Äúfib‚Äù for too long! Thanks, Victor!
There's a new NYT game called "pips".

Ouch, sometimes for us Brits, it‚Äôs like doing a crossword in a different language. However, I‚Äôve done enough NYT puzzles to know domain names of colleges and the Five Nations Tribes,  although many American colloquialisms and idioms escape me. Definitely a great hook that this dicey puzzle is linked to the new game.
Help! The puzzle app says my crossword puzzle isn't complete, but I can't find any errors and moreover I can't edit the puzzle. Whom should I contact?

Today‚Äôs puzzle was fine without really floating my boat. Worked out the DIE/PIP theme ok. This felt easier than yesterday‚Äôs grid. Mr Shortz is clearly mixing it up.

Had a look at the PIPs game. Its numbers, ergo not for me. I‚Äôll stick to Wordle, strands and Spelling Bee thanks,
I solved the 8/20/2025 New York Times Mini Crossword in 1:37! https://fpx3r.app.goo.gl/PKC4 Enjoyed this one. Been long since i did a crossword
Took me way too long to figure out the theme. The revealers at the center of the puzzle were the last spaces I filled in. Once I got it , I said and did the clue/answer for 38D.
Wait, what, no other O's anywhere except the pips?? That's some lovely polish, in a fun puzzle!

Before I go to the Column and other Comments, I just want to say this:  I solved the puzzle.  I'm sure I solved it correctly.  I read ALL the clues.  I write "American HAIKU" myself, following traditional themes.  
I am sure there is something more in this puzzle that I'm not 'getting,' but this week has not allowed me the normal time I have to spend cogitating over a complicated theme, let alone any extra minutes, to bend my brain around...  so:
 Hail, aptly named Victor Schmitt, Winner who hammered out this puzzle, leaving me....Puzzled!
Speaking of PIPs https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HwbmufPphP0

I was a little late noticing the the look of the die because I was distracted trying to figure out if the letters meant anything.  It was a nice little surprise when it hit me, and I went back and darkened all of those O's.

I always appreciate the extras like not having any other O's in the puzzle.  Victor must have gone through some trouble to pull that off, so I just want to say that I noticed.
How many of us thought 67A was DAN?

Just wondering if anyone is actually enjoying the Pips puzzle so far. I was underwhelmed yesterday and having solved the difficult puzzle today in 2 minutes I‚Äôm not feeling it. I think it will be a pass for me going forward.
10:16. Cute theme today! PIP is a fun word.
Loved this one! What a fun theme.

"Not today, SEITAN!"


Didn't Johnny Cash sing "A Trex Named Sue"?
Loved this one!  Work of art.
I done did this puzz

Just saw in the news that a certain Congresswoman in New York tried to make a speech in her district yesterday, but was BOOOFFSTAGE by her constituents.
I guess they were telling her "no dice".
Woo, what a dilly!!
Anybody else have flashbacks to *that* aunt coming towards you as you wrote in, incorrectly, wet KISS?  Yuck!
i am too stupid to get the o messages but solved it anyway. I will look again. I do love these puzzles and I am  bringing my adult and faraway children along with shared screens video calls.

I had a Na... er... problem with SEITAN / ANI.

Pips on a die? Meh.
762 streak.
Oh wow. I got slowed down by a PuRITY / PARITY problem, but this is brilliant grid art.  Love the way there are no Os anywhere else in the puzzle besides the die faces.

SPOILER ALERT! Scabbers is not really a PET RAT, he's a dark wizard named Peter Pettigrew. who takes that form to SPY on Lord Voldemort's enemies...for twelve years. Wow, that's some dedication to evil. Also a bit of a plot hole, as it's never explained how he came to be in the Weasleys' possession after betraying Harry's parents to the Dark Lord.

Oh right, the puzzle. I spent way too much time trying to make sense of the letters in the shaded squares. Is OSCAR TOIL a thing? Nope, no wordplay, just dice. I do like Yahtzee, but that only has five of them.
Well crafted challenge Viktor!...but, imho, Editor(s), a bit  onerous for a Wednesday....

Singer DiFranco crossed with Writer Allende is diabolical - the other crosses aren't much better. Barely limped through the SE corner.

The theme here was good fun, though

The buzzing around SEITAN today reminded me of the first time I ever had it: Baby Watson's in the Garage in Harvard Square served a breaded, fried seitan that was juicy and delicious. 

Today I found the theme helpful--it allowed me to watch for the o's and fill in some of the later ones by process of elimination. And, like many others, I loved the longer answers, especially BOO OFFSTAGE.

Clue: When a crossword theme proves to be no help in solving individual crosses and is a hardly a "delightful solve."
Answer: Underwhelming
rolling through this until I hit SE corner - yeouch!

Took me a minute to get the idea after the solve. My only grievance is that on the face of a die the portion that is not a PIP is a solid surface not filled with letters. So for me it‚Äôs a bit of a head scratcher.
MSG didn't throw me but the clue was a little off base. MSG is a flavor enhancer and not a flavor itself, no?
After seeing the theme, I had to wonder why the clue for 3D wasn‚Äôt tied into it too, as this die is being ROLLED.

30% allow5ed than my average.    I kept thinking th at all the letters in each box had a meaning, but alas they did not.    Seems like an incredibly tough puzzle to create, so kudos to the constructor.     Felt more like a Thursday to me.
What a great puzzle!  Good fun.
This was so delightful. Well done Victor!

Not a difficult solve for me. I didn't get the theme - I thought DIE meant that there were different ways of expressing DIE in the shaded areas, like 'pop off' etc!

I got all the clues I didn't know through the crossers, which is how it should be.
That was fun. Much faster for me than yesterday's.
Loved it! Wednesdays are always the wonkiest in terms of how they trend difficulty-wise, so sure this was easier with the shorter fill, but the construction was very clever and satisfying.

Loved it. Thought about the six being opposite the one, two opposite the five, to maintain dice symmetry, but that's fine. It was probably not an easy puzzle to construct! 

50D is a complete unknown to me. "Betty Frenemy" unlocked a lot, as did 14A and 17A which were insta-gets.
Calling Yoko Ono a musician is like calling Trump a diplomat
Appropriate puzzle to accompany the release of "Pips"! Excited for the new NYT game.

Kudos to Victor Schmitt!! What an impressive feat of puzzle construction.  Constraining all of the O‚Äôs in the puzzle to be pips, then creating all six faces of the die in the puzzle is really awesome. Well done!

I think if the O‚Äôs had been filled in upon completion to become true pips, that would have made for an impressive finish. Missed opportunity for the flashy graphics folks.  

I had wetKISS before DOGKISS, then it became DOtKISS. I thought, ‚ÄúIs that a thing?‚Äù. 

Similarly, had NOsIPS before NOTIPS for Japanese food service.  I certainly didn‚Äôt remember the Japanese chugging tea or sake when I was there long ago.

Nifty puzzle. I enjoyed the device and I thought the fill was pretty darn fresh given the constraints. 

Bit of a clueing quibble on 40A, though - if TUNES is to "fix" my piano, then it's broken every six months!

Not related to today‚Äôs puzzle but I am petitioning to the NYT to keep Sunday grids at normal size. Large grids with medium difficulty are generally a sloth to solve and always break my streak. I am not too concerned with streaks but it does break the momentum and lessen the enthusiasm to timely attack subsequent puzzles. Not sure if others have same issue, maybe not those who have lots of time on their Sundays.
Just tedious, not humorous.
I really enjoyed this puzzle's theme. Perfect combo of fun and also giving you a bit of a hint for clues you haven't solved yet.

When I saw the theme was related to the faces of a die, I was hoping one of my favorite words would find its way into the puzzle: QUINCUNX, which is the name for the arrangement of 5 pips on a standard die or domino. Alas, no dice!
Shouldn't the clue for 13D be "Scabber" to match the singular entry?
Was stuck for so long on "Delivers, as a baby" !! I was sure it was OBS
It was a treat to see my fondness for crosswords and compassion intersecting at 50D.
As an avid D&D player, any puzzle that incorporates dice is a winner for me.

"Pip pip! Pip pip!"

- Tartuffe, the Spry Wonderdog
365-day streak! ü•≥

Why oh why can‚Äôt you show the puzzle title in the app? Sometimes it holds an important clue; sometimes it just adds to the entertainment value. Surely if you can credit the author and editor (which is great) you could also make room for the title?
Clever and fun - A Wednesday gem!
wonderful puzzle! thanks victor!
Clever puzzle! Loved the 'gimmick.'
Hard for a Wednesday; more like Friday, or even Saturday. I had to guess on three or four, and guessed wrong, which I hardly ever do. SEITAN? ALMA? PAM? MMA? ANI? SUE? SUNOCO? Never heard of ‚Äòem.
Challenging and fun. I had to find my mistake when I thought I was all done. It was 57 Down, where I had mAD in place of FAD. Silly of me, but it seemed to make sense for a while. ü§™
I'm really enjoying Pips. Makes me exercise a different part of my brain.

It was a good, challenging Wednesday puzzle - a fail for me.

Even after I finally found my mistake and finished the puzzle, I had to look at at it a few times to makes sense out of the theme.

The puzzle us cleverly constructed, but the reveal left me cold.
Having worked for various segments of Sun Oil over the years, "SUNOCO" was a nice appearance, and the trademark's O's are handy for puzzle constructors.
South East corner is Natick central. Yech. I'm not sure I'm working any of that out. Luckily, I have watched just enough NASCAR to get SUNOCO, but even that isn't helping. Back to the grind...

Somehow I wasn't really feeling this game until I saw (can I say this? SPOILER ALERT) three Os in a row and it wasn't an error on my part like it usually is!

So I was impressed at that, and yet even with the clues to the theme (which I won't give away), it wasn't until I finished that I had a chance to really register what he was doing.  I ALWAYS like a visual element of some kind, and this one was really solid.

So as it sank in, I really enjoyed it.  A minute twenty seconds over my average for the day, which I think adds to the satisfaction.

@jennie

Actors and musians come from there.  Jay Silverheels, who played Tonto in the Lone Ranger was a Mohawk, Grahame Greene (Dances with Wolves, Northern Exposure) is Oneida,
Robbie Roberston from the group The Band was Cayuga and Mohawk.

@jennie

As a New York State resident, I have to differ with you.  The number used depends on what era you're talking about, and in the current era, the peoples under this umbrella term, which still is used, total six:  the Seneca, Cayuga, Onondaga, Oneida, and Mohawk, and the latecomers, the Tuscarora.  

The proper endonym for this confederation is Haudenosaunee, meaning "people of the longhouse," but the exonym Iroquois is also commonly used.  The territory in which they reside covers most of upstate New York and parts of adjacent Canada.  Until recently, they were allowed to issue passports and declared war on Germany in both world wars.

I'd say that was after the 1600s.

@Ian Hookham - there‚Äôs no joke to explain; you‚Äôre reading the clue wrong. Americans don‚Äôt say Sat Nav. We say GPS; to Brits, that‚Äôs Sat Nav.

We get this all the time. Think:
Clue: What the Brits call a rubber
Answer: can be either ‚Äúrubber‚Äù or ‚Äúeraser‚Äù,
because the clue can be interpreted as either

What the Brits call [what we call] a rubber
or
What [we call that] the Brits call a rubber

So the clue Sat ___ (GPS, to Brits)
is perfectly fine.

@Bill
A couple more fun facts about Etruscan: the early Romans were quite in awe of the Etruscans, and adopted many of their social institutions, and some of their vocabulary, from them--which were then passed down to us. So, whenever a Brit might talk about using "*Satellite* Navigation for directions to the *arena*," they're speaking Etruscan.

Also, the Roman format for personal names-- a first name, drawn from a finite and quite limited set, followed by a familial name, passed down from generation to generation (Gaius Julius [Caesar], e.g.) --which is the format most Europeans use today--was most likely adopted from Etruscan. In Rome, the number of first names (prraenomen) was so limited, that most were just abbreviated in writing: C. Julius Caesar ("C." standing for "Gaius," because, well, reasons.)

This is in contrast to the original Indo-European system, in which most personal names consisted of two stems: Al-fred, Sieg-fried, Vladi-mir. When further clarification was needed, a patronymic was used:  Siegfried son of Siegmund.

@B -- Tempeh is my favorite soy food.  For many, it is an acquired taste.  As you are a fan of it yourself, how about a recipe????

@B -- Thank you, I appreciate your cooking tips.  Re tempeh, I've gotten to where if I just fry it in olive oil over low to medium heat so it doesn't splatter, then flip it after it nicely browns, and after I flip it put some shoyu or soy sauce over the top -- that by itself tastes great.  Anything else, like adding it to a stir fry, or topping it with a sauce or chili crisp, is gravy, so to speak.

@Lewis

Yep exactly, as the protein in any stir fry or noodle dish it's great, and it's also nicely filling in a sandwich or wrap, adding savoryness, substance, and crunch in a meat/bacon way.  Oh, and I don't do this as often as I should, but it's a good thing to crumble (before cookIng) for chili and such.  For me it's far, far better than tofu in basically any application.  Relatedly I will also confess my shame that I have developed an unholy fondness for chip style Bacos (a discontinued brand but that's what I still call them) with some mayo on bread as t base for a rather pathetic yet darn tasty quick BLT analog. @Remy

The big Sunday puzzle is a long-standing tradition in the newspaper, long before the internet.

When I was a wee kid, the local paper carried the syndicated NYT Sunday puzzle, a week late. My mother claimed that part of the paper as her own, and it often took her several days to finish the puzzle. Then she'd wait until the next Sunday to check the answers.

Being a larger puzzle than the daily is part of the Sunday puzzle's mystique.

@Lynn

Thanks Lynn, Linda Jo and everyone else who responded.  I like all inputs that expand my perspective on things and hasty judgments on my character from people with opposite view on this forum don‚Äôt alter my mood for the day or fray my temper one bit.  Not at all. :)

@Remy

The bigger consideration is not just the size making the difficulty more difficult but that there are clues and themes that can‚Äôt be accommodated in a 15x15 size. So think of all the great puzzles that you would miss. Just as one example the recent Star Trek puzzle could never have been done in a 15 x 15. Sorry everyone jumped down you throat, but you really did phrase it badly‚Äîstarting out with ‚Äúit breaks my streak‚Äù really does make you sound shallow even if you didn‚Äôt mean it that way. In any case a lot of people wait with bated breath (me too) for Sundays so this isn‚Äôt going to happen.

@Remy
One vote to keep large Sundays.
Aside from the other points in favor, it's a link to my childhood watching my parents find a way to coexist over it (after deciding that doing it together did NOT fly). 
 They bought a big gum eraser and agreed the first one up on Sunday got to do it IN PENCIL and then had to carefully erase the the entire thing. Worked for them!
I only got into any of it in adulthood. My mother started doing the daily mostly after my father died.

Remy,

Nobody on this thread judged your character, hastily or otherwise. Not at all. There was, to be sure, some questioning of your judgment.

But, as you say, that's democracy, right?

@Remy Sundays, though larger and a test of my eyesight on my phone, are a nice break after the challenge of Fri and Sat as they are a Wed/Thurs level. That level of challenge is my sweet spot and the longer solve holds me over through the quick beginning of the week puzzles.
@Remy If you are nailing the Saturday puzzle and having issues with Sunday is it possible the issue is just your device? I find Sundays horrible on the phone, much easier on a tablet.
